section: Section 2 - Codes and amateur radio abbreviations. Rules and procedures for conducting amateur radio communications

questions.question_body: What should you do before you start transmitting on a specific frequency?
questions.A: Listen to the frequency to make sure no one is currently using it
questions.B: Transmit a few short statements to make sure someone hears you
questions.C: Check if your antenna is resonant at that frequency
questions.D: Check if the SWR of your antenna is good enough

questions.question_body: If you have established a radio contact with another station and your signal is exceptionally strong and perfectly intelligible, what adjustment to your transmitter could you make?
questions.A: Reduce the gain of the microphone amplifier
questions.C: Reduce the transmitter power to the minimum necessary
questions.D: Continue the radio contact without any changes (what more could you want from it?)

questions.question_body: How can you reduce the transmission time when tuning the final stage of the transmitter to avoid unnecessary interference?
questions.A: By connecting an arbitrary wire as an antenna
questions.B: By tuning the transmitter first outside the amateur radio band and then switching to it
questions.C: By using a dummy load instead of an antenna
questions.D: By using a balanced line instead of coaxial cable for connection to the antenna

questions.question_body: If you are conducting a radio contact with another station and you hear a distress message on the frequency, what should you do?
questions.A: Inform the station transmitting the message that the frequency is busy
questions.B: Direct the station transmitting the message to the nearest emergency frequency
questions.C: Call the nearest police station and notify the duty officer of the transmitted message
questions.D: Immediately terminate your QSO and receive the distress message

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "CQ"?
questions.A: Testing a new antenna (no radio station should respond)
questions.C: Only the called radio station should respond
questions.D: Calling all stations

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "DX"?
questions.A: Best wishes
questions.C: Calling all stations
questions.D: Begin transmission

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "73"?
questions.A: Distant radio station
questions.C: Love and kisses
questions.D: Begin transmission

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "88"?
questions.A: Distant radio station
questions.C: Love and kisses
questions.D: Begin transmission

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the code "QTH"?
questions.A: Time
questions.C: Stop transmitting
questions.D: Location

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the code "QRM"?
questions.A: I am busy
questions.B: Another station is interfering with your signal
questions.C: Your signal has strong mains hum
questions.D: Stop transmitting

questions.question_body: The code "QRL" means?
questions.A: I will send my card
questions.C: I am transmitting with low power
questions.D: My location is

questions.question_body: The code "QRP" means?
questions.A: I receive your signal with interference
questions.C: I am transmitting with low power
questions.D: I am transmitting with a portable antenna

questions.question_body: The code "QSO" means?
questions.A: Low power
questions.C: Radio contact
questions.D: Location

questions.question_body: Which Q code will you use to announce that you are ceasing transmission?
questions.A: QTH
questions.C: QRT
questions.D: QSL

questions.question_body: Which of the listed codes and abbreviations is most often transmitted at the end of a radio contact?
questions.C: QTH
questions.D: QRP

questions.question_body: What is a QSL card?
questions.A: A letter or postcard from a friend - radio amateur
questions.C: Written proof of radio contact between two radio amateurs
questions.D: A postcard with notice of acquired amateur radio class

questions.question_body: How should you respond to a "CQ" call?
questions.A: Say the call sign of the calling radio station at least ten times, followed by the words "this is" and then your call sign said three times
questions.B: Say phonetically the call sign of the calling radio station at least five times, followed by the words "this is" and then your call sign said at least once
questions.C: Say the call sign of the calling radio station at least three times, followed by the words "this is" and then your call sign said phonetically at least five times
questions.D: Say the call sign of the calling radio station once, followed by the words "this is" and then your call sign said phonetically

questions.question_body: To make your call sign more understandable, what should you do?
questions.A: Use the international phonetic alphabet for each letter of the call sign
questions.B: Use appropriate words beginning with the same letter as each letter of the call sign
questions.C: Speak louder
questions.D: Increase the gain of the microphone amplifier

questions.question_body: What does simplex operation mean?
questions.A: Transmitting and receiving on the same frequency
questions.B: Transmitting to and receiving from another country
questions.C: Transmitting on one frequency and receiving on another
questions.D: Transmitting a one-way message

questions.question_body: When should you use simplex instead of a repeater?
questions.A: When the most reliable radio contact is needed
questions.B: When radio contact is possible without using a repeater
questions.C: When urgent message transmission is necessary
questions.D: When traveling and needing local information

questions.question_body: What is the correct way to establish radio contact through a repeater?
questions.A: Say the call sign of the radio station you want to contact three times
questions.B: Say the name of the operator you want to contact three times, then your call sign three times
questions.C: Say the call sign of the radio station you want to contact, then your call sign
questions.D: Say "Break", then your call sign

questions.question_body: When using a repeater for radio contact, what must you know about it besides its input frequency?
questions.A: Its output frequency
questions.C: Its power
questions.D: The type of its antenna system

questions.question_body: What is the main purpose of amateur repeaters?
questions.A: To provide local information 24 hours a day
questions.B: To connect radio amateurs to a telephone system
questions.C: To retransmit weather information
questions.D: To increase the operating range of amateur radio stations

questions.question_body: What does it mean for a repeater to have input and output frequency?
questions.A: The repeater receives on one frequency and transmits on another
questions.B: The repeater must receive its tone code on one frequency to start retransmitting the received signal on the other
questions.C: One frequency is used for repeater control, and the other for retransmitting the received signal
questions.D: None of the three

questions.question_body: If you have established a radio contact with LZ1AW, how will you pronounce his call sign phonetically?
questions.A: Lima, Zulu, one, Alfa, Whiskey
questions.C: Either of the above two ways
questions.D: El, zet, edinitsa, A, Double vee

questions.question_body: If you have established a radio contact with Z36BAL, how will you pronounce his call sign phonetically?
questions.A: Zakhari, tri, shest, Boris, Anton, Lyudmil
questions.B: Zulu, three, six, Bravo, Alfa, Lima
questions.C: Zanzibar, tri, shest, Baltimore, America, London
questions.D: Zet, triyset i shest, Be, A, El

questions.question_body: If you are calling YU1DS for a radio contact and your call sign is LZ1HCP, how will you pronounce it phonetically?
questions.A: Lyudmil, Zakhari, edinitsa, Nikolay, Stefan, Rumen
questions.B: Lyudmil, Zakhari, edinitsa, Hristo, Tsvetan, Petar
questions.C: Lima, Zulu, one, Hotel, Charlie, Papa
questions.D: Lima, Zulu, edinitsa, November, Sierra, Romeo

questions.question_body: Which organization is NOT a radio amateur organization?
questions.A: International Telecommunication Union
questions.C: Bulgarian Federation of Radio Amateurs
questions.D: Working Group on High Speed Telegraphy of IARU, Region 1

questions.question_body: What is a "QTH" locator?
questions.A: A device for determining location
questions.B: A system of coded information about the location of an amateur radio station
questions.C: A device for determining exact coordinates via satellite navigation
questions.D: An abbreviation for LOw Quality TrAnsisTOR

questions.question_body: Your QSL card to a foreign radio amateur should be sent via?
questions.A: Bulgarian Federation of Radio Amateurs
questions.C: The QSL Bureau of the foreign radio amateur
questions.D: By your choice

questions.question_body: What does the RS rating mean?
questions.A: Readability and signal strength at the receiving location
questions.B: Overall signal quality at the receiving location
questions.C: Rating for interference strength at the receiving location
questions.D: Rating for signal quality after being retransmitted by an amateur repeater

questions.question_body: What is the maximum RS rating?
Which of the following is NOT an RS rating?
Is it permissible for a radio amateur to transmit weather information during a radio contact?
questions.A: No, because the information can only be communicated by authorized services
questions.C: No, because it is outside purely amateur radio matters
questions.D: Yes, but only using Morse code

questions.question_body: Is it permissible for a radio amateur to transmit information about their radio equipment during a radio contact?
questions.A: Yes
questions.B: Yes, but only those specified in the Rules for the use of radio frequency spectrum for radio equipment from amateur radio service (the Rules)
questions.C: No, because it is not explicitly mentioned in the Rules
questions.D: No, because it is prohibited by the Rules

questions.question_body: To which country does the call sign S51SV belong?
questions.A: Greece
questions.C: Turkey
questions.D: Slovenia

questions.question_body: To which country does the call sign TA1YU belong?
questions.A: Greece
questions.C: Turkey
questions.D: Slovenia

questions.question_body: To which neighboring country does the call sign SV3YO belong?
questions.A: Macedonia
questions.C: Turkey
questions.D: Romania

questions.question_body: To which neighboring country does the call sign Z31TA belong?
questions.A: Macedonia
questions.C: Turkey
questions.D: Romania

questions.question_body: To which country does the call sign YO6YU belong?
questions.A: Slovenia
questions.C: Turkey
questions.D: Romania

questions.question_body: From which country is a radio amateur transmitting with the call sign YO/LZ1AW?
questions.A: From Romania
questions.C: From the border between Romania and Bulgaria
questions.D: From Bulgaria, but through a Romanian amateur repeater

questions.question_body: Do radio amateurs from neighboring countries have the right to conduct radio communications through a Bulgarian amateur repeater?
questions.A: They do not have the right
questions.C: They have the right, but only with Bulgarian radio amateurs
questions.D: They have the right if they comply with the Rules

questions.question_body: Do radio amateurs from Bulgaria have the right to conduct radio communications through amateur repeaters located in other countries?
questions.A: They do not have the right
questions.C: They have the right, but only with Bulgarian radio amateurs
questions.D: They have the right, but only with radio amateurs from the respective country

questions.question_body: If you hear the call sign LZ1AW/1, this means?
questions.A: LZ1AW is using a portable station
questions.B: LZ1AW is using a radio station with a power of 1 watt
questions.C: LZ1AW's wife is using his radio station
questions.D: LZ1AW is operating from his cottage in Sozopol

questions.question_body: If you hear the call sign LZ1AW/2, this means?
questions.A: LZ1AW is using his radio station while driving his car
questions.B: LZ1AW is operating from a friend's apartment in Ruse
questions.C: LZ1AW is operating from his cottage in Sozopol
questions.D: LZ1AW indicates that he is operating through repeater #2

questions.question_body: If you hear the call sign LZ1AW/M, this means?
questions.A: LZ1AW is using his radio station while driving his car
questions.C: LZ1AW is only working with stations participating in the ongoing contest
questions.D: LZ1AW is operating from aboard a watercraft

questions.question_body: If you hear LZ1AW transmitting CQ DX, does this apply to you?
questions.A: No, this applies only to distant stations
questions.B: Yes, it applies to all stations
questions.C: No, unless you haven't heard from each other for a long time
questions.D: Yes, but after such a call you must switch to another amateur radio band

questions.question_body: What is recorded in the station logbook?
questions.A: Date and time of radio contact
questions.C: RS signal rating
questions.D: All of these

questions.question_body: If you are transmitted the message Q5, this means?
questions.A: That the radio contact is being conducted through an amateur repeater
questions.B: Your QSL card is of maximum quality
questions.C: Please wait 5 minutes
questions.D: The amateur radio prefix of the Republic of Macedonia

questions.question_body: If you are filling out a QSL card for a radio amateur from a neighboring country, what time of radio contact will you record?
questions.A: The hour and minute in Bulgarian time
questions.B: The hour and minute in the time of the neighboring country
questions.C: The hour and minute in universal time
questions.D: You do not need to indicate hour and minute

questions.question_body: If you are communicating your name to the radio amateur with whom you are in radio contact, how will you do it?
questions.A: My name is Alexander
questions.C: My name is Alexander Georgiev
questions.D: My name is Alexander Petrov Georgiev

questions.question_body: When participating in a radio amateur contest, the main goal is?
questions.A: Maximum QRL time
questions.C: Maximum fast QRT
questions.D: Maximum number of QSOs

questions.question_body: Why is it necessary to use short messages when transmitting through a repeater?
questions.A: To preserve the radio station battery for a longer time
questions.B: To give everyone who is not a radio amateur a chance to respond
questions.C: Longer messages can prevent someone with an urgent distress message from using the repeater
questions.D: To check if the receiving radio station is still on the line

questions.question_body: What is the correct way to join a conversation through a repeater?
questions.A: You call one of the correspondents by name and join the QSO
questions.B: You announce your presence and desire to join by calling "break, break!" and wait for a response
questions.C: You turn on the amplifier and drown out whoever is speaking
questions.D: You announce your call sign in the pause between transmitted emissions from other radio amateurs

questions.question_body: When talking to another radio station through a repeater, how can you tell if you can use simplex?
questions.A: If a third station hears you both
questions.B: If you can receive a more distant repeater
questions.C: If you can receive the radio station with good quality on the repeater's receive frequency
questions.D: In no way

questions.question_body: When choosing a transmit frequency, what do you need to do?
questions.A: Check that the selected frequency and emission class are permitted according to my amateur radio class
questions.B: Check that the maximum output power of the transmitter corresponds to the power permitted for my amateur radio class
questions.C: Listen to the frequency before transmitting
questions.D: All three answers are correct
